description: From Middle English milte, from Old English milte, milt (“milt, spleen”), from Proto-West Germanic *miltijā, *meltā, from Proto-Germanic *meltǭ (“spleen”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)meld- (“to beat, grind, crush, weaken”). Cognate with German Milz, Dutch milt, Danish milt, Norwegian milt, Swedish mjälte. Outside Germanic, with Albanian mëlçi (“liver”).

entries.meaning: (countable) The spleen, especially of an animal bred for food.
examples: Adam Kadmon had pneumonia. Friar Goat cured it by tying a bullock’s milt to the soles of the lad’s feet, and burying the milt afterwards. Adam Kadmon immediately contracted the thrush.

entries.meaning: The semen of a male fish.

verbs.description: milt (third-person singular simple present milts, present participle milting, simple past and past participle milted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impregnate (the roe of a fish) with milt.
